Introduction to limits
Some words.
Suppose p(x)=F(x)S(x) where the 'first' function F = F(x) and the 'second' function S = S(x) are both differentiable. Then \begin{aligned}[t] p'(x) \amp= F(x)S'(x)+S(x)F'(x)\\ \frac{dp}{dx}\amp= F(x)\cdot \frac{dS}{dx} + S(x) \cdot \frac{dF}{dx} \end{aligned}
-->
Basic quotient rule
Suppose w(x)=(x-3)(x+2). Find w'(x).
\begin{aligned}[t] w'(x) \amp= \frac{d}{dx}\left((x-3)(x+2)\right)\\ \amp= (x-3)\frac{d}{dx}(x+2) + (x+2)\frac{d}{dx}(x-3)\\ \amp= (x-3)(1) + (x+2)(1)\\ w'(x) \amp= 2x-1 \end{aligned}
Notice that we could have expanded w(x) first by multiplying the right-hand side, then taken the derivative of the result term-by-term.
